name: portulaca-oleracea
country-or-region-of-origin: Western Asia, Mediterranean,  likey ancient anthropogenic disper
wildlife-value: Attracts flowers flies, small bees and beetles, sparrow, deer. Low use as food for large mammals.
edibility: Stems, leaves, and flowers are edible and have a slightly sour and salty taste. It cooks similar to spinach. It is eaten throughout Europe, the Middle East, and Mexico. Is edible and very nutritious because it contains high amounts of omega 3 fatty acids, significant amounts of vitamins A and C and anti-oxidants.  Leaves, stems and flowers can be eaten raw, as in a salad, or boiled. Taste is sour or tart and salty. Mucilaginous quality works to thicken soups or stews.  Seeds are also edible.Contains oxalates that can be toxic in if eaten in high amounts.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: An egg-shaped capsule that will scatter tiny, black, shiny seed when it splits open.
flower-description: Flowers are small (1/4 inch), yellow, and have five heart-shaped petals that can appear any time of year. They can be found in the cluster of leaves at the stem end and they open only briefly in the morning hours.
leaf-description: Smooth, fleshy (thick and succulent) oval leaves that tend to be clustered at joints and stem ends.  In bright sunlight, the leaves can take on a tinge of reddish-purple.  Young leaves have a maroon tint on the underside.
stem-description: Stems are round, thick and succulent.  They can be light green to reddish-brown in color.  Each stem has multiple branches that create circular mats.
poison-symptoms: Kidney failure (rare in dogs/cats), tremors, salivation.
poison-toxic-principle: Soluble calcium oxalates. Oxalate accumuation, renal problems, hamful to livestock in high amounts
